q:
In C#, you are working on Pattern Matching. Which of the following deductions can be made about the var declaration used in the case expression in the code snippet given below?

Code

static object ShapeObjects(string shapeExplain)
{
    switch (shapeExplain)
    {
        case "circle":
        return new Circle(2);
        
        case "square":
        return new Square(4);

        case "large-circle":
        return new Circle(12);
        
        case var o when (o?.Trim().Length ?? 0) == 0:
        return null;
        
        default:
        return "the shape explanation is not valid";
        
    }
}



Deductions

  1. var declaration has the null check which is included in the type pattern expressions.


     

  2. var declaration follows the normal type inference rules that are the type inferred to be the static type of the switch expression.

What is the output of the following C code:

    #include<stdio.h>
    int main()
    {
        int choice = 1 ;
        switch(choice,choice+1,choice+2)
        {
            case 1:
            printf("\nA");
            break;
            case 2:
            printf("\nB");
            break;
            case 3:
            printf("\nH");
            break;
        }
    }

What is the output of the following C code:

 #include <stdio.h>

    void main()
    {
        int choice = 2 ;
        switch(choice)
        {
        }
    }

What is the output of the following C code:

#include<stdio.h>
int  main()
{
    int hackvar = 2 ;
    switch(hackvar << 1)
    {
        case 2:
            hackfunc1(hackvar);
            break;
        case 4:
            hackfunc2(hackvar);
            break;    
     }
}
int hackfunc1(int hackvar)
{
    int hackvar1 = hackvar;
    switch(hackvar1<<2)
    {
        case 2:
        printf(2+2*2-2);
        break;
        case 4:
        printf(3+3+3*3);
        break;
    }
}
int hackfunc2(int hackvar)
{
    int hackvar2 = hackvar;
    switch(hackvar2<<3)
    {
        case 2:
        printf(2+2+2+2);
        break;
        case 4:
        printf(3+3*3+3);
        break;
    }
}

What is the output of the following C++ code:

#include <iostream>
using namespace std;
int main()
{
    int x = 0;
    switch (x) {
    case 1:
        cout << "Hacker";
    case 0:
        cout << "Earth";
    }
}

What is the output of the following C code:

    #include<stdio.h>
    int main()
    {
        int choice = 7;
        switch (choice)
        {
            printf("A");
            default:
            printf("D");
            break;
            case 1:
            printf("E");
            break;
        }
    }

What is the output of the following C code:

    #include<stdio.h>
    int main()
    {
        int choice = 1 ;
        switch(choice)
        {
            case 'A':
            case 'a':
            printf("\nA");
            break;
            case 'B':
            case 'b':
            printf("\nB");
            break;
        }
    }
In PHP, which of the following keywords is used to handle the cases that are not defined with the case keyword?

What will be the output of the following C# code?

Code:

using System;

class Hackerearth 
{
    static public void Main()
	{
		var hack = "23";
		
		switch (hack) {

		case "14":
			Console.WriteLine("hi");
			break;
			
		case "15":
			Console.WriteLine("hello");
			break;
			
		case "20":
		    Console.WriteLine("hack");
			break;
			
		case "23":
			Console.WriteLine("Hackerearth");

			goto case "15" ;

		default:
			Console.WriteLine("hello world");
			break;
		}
	}
}


Output

  1. Hackerearth
hello

     
  2. Hackerearth

     
  3. Hackerearth
hello world

a.option: The code gives a compilation error

q:
In Networking, which of the following statements about switches is correct?  

  1. Switches forward packets based on the IP address.
  2. Switches forward packets based on the IPX address.
  3. Switches forward packets based on the Layer3 protocol.
  4. Switches forward packets based on the MAC address.

What is the output of the following Java 8 code?
Code:

class HackerEarth{
  public static void main(String[] args)
  {
    int a = 0;
    int b = 3;
    while(++a < 3)
    {
    int c = --a + b++;
    switch(b)
      {
        default:
        case 0: a = ++a + a--;
        case 1: a += a-- + ++b;
      }
    }
    System.out.println(a);
  }
}
